@paultag @konklone Again, conflating the website developer with the browser user is a huge logical fallacy in this whole thing. All you've done is made someone switch to Chrome because "Firefox is broken for that site". Same way we do with IE.
@konklone But it *doesnt* prevent the websites from doing *anything*, it only prevents the *browser users*. This is a fundamental disconnect, a logical fallacy.
@konklone It's like saying "all roads should have traffic lights and we're disabling your tires until they do."

@konklone There's a fundamental disconnect in logic between a *web developer* choosing to use a technology (CSS), a *web server* supporting HTTPS, and a *user* using a particular browser. Firefox isn't forcing users to use HTTPS, only breaking websites that don't. Backwards.

@konklone I understand the principle, but the cudgel is aimed at the wrong target. Punishing browser *users* does not help the cause of furthering security. If you want real change, the focus should be on webserver vendors. This is totally misguided strong-arming.

@konklone This is an overly-dramatic overreach. You can prioritize secure connections without deliberately hobbling the underlying technology. Pretending that CSS features have anything to do with security only undermines the argument here.
The notion that new CSS features will be limited to only HTTPS-compliant sites is appalling. So much for the open web. https://t.co/BFWNsxb3m2
